unnormalised: My grandmother, Amma, always said cooking was an art, not a science. But even art needs its measurements, she’d chuckle, pointing to her well-worn recipe book. I remember, as a kid, being fascinated by the mix of precise figures and vague instructions scrawled across the pages. For instance, her signature biryani recipe called for "2 cups" of rice, but then “a pinch” of saffron. Trying to recreate her magic in the kitchen was always a bit of a guessing game, especially with those pinches!

unnormalised: One Diwali, I attempted her gulab jamun recipe. It called for 250 gms of khoya, 100 gms of maida, and “a little” baking soda. "Little" turned out to be way too much, and the poor jamuns exploded in the ghee, creating a sugary mess! Amma, bless her heart, just laughed, handing me a cup of chai and saying, "Next time, measure the baking soda. Maybe about 1/4 tsp."
normalised: One Diwali, I attempted her gulab jamun recipe. It called for two hundred and fifty grams of khoya, one hundred grams of maida, and “a little” baking soda. "Little" turned out to be way too much, and the poor jamuns exploded in the ghee, creating a sugary mess! Amma, bless her heart, just laughed, handing me a cup of chai and saying, "Next time, measure the baking soda. Maybe about one fourth teaspoon."

unnormalised: It’s funny how some measurements feel so intuitive now. I can glance at a vegetable and know roughly how many grams it weighs. I’ve learned that "a splash" of milk is about 50 ml, and "a knob" of butter is around 1 tbsp. But it took years of practice, and many a kitchen mishap, to develop that sense. I even bought a weighing scale that measures to the nearest 0.1 g, to precisely replicate some of the trickier recipes.
normalised: It’s funny how some measurements feel so intuitive now. I can glance at a vegetable and know roughly how many grams it weighs. I even bought a weighing scale that measures to the nearest zero point one gram, to precisely replicate some of the trickier recipes.

unnormalised: Recently, I was trying to recreate my mother’s sambar. Her recipe simply stated "tamarind – small lemon sized ball". After a lengthy phone call, I finally figured out that was around 30 grams! It made me appreciate the standardized measurements we have today, even if Amma’s “pinch” of saffron had a certain nostalgic charm.

unnormalised: Now, I try to be as precise as possible when sharing recipes. "15 ml" instead of a splash, "200 g" instead of "a handful". Still, I can't help but leave a little bit of Amma’s vagueness in there. After all, isn't that what makes cooking so much fun? That flexibility, that artistic license. But trust me, start with the 1/4 tsp of baking soda. Your gulab jamuns will thank you for it!
